keyTakeAways: A Slovak court convicted 72-year-old poet Juraj Cintula of a 'terror attack' and sentenced him to 21 years in prison for shooting Prime Minister Robert Fico on May 15, 2024.

The shooting occurred during a government meeting in central Slovakia, with Cintula claiming he was driven by 'moral despair' and wanted to protest against Fico’s government policies, including the halt of military aid to Ukraine.
Prosecutors reclassified the crime from premeditated murder to a 'terror attack' due to Cintula’s political motivation, emphasizing the act as an expression of political dissent.
Cintula claimed in his final statement that Fico embodied years of national frustration and that his actions were fueled by arrogance, corruption, and irrational decisions.

Fico, who is now serving his fourth term, has faced criticism for increasing alignment with Russia, opposing EU sanctions, and implementing authoritarian policies, including crackdowns on media and nonprofit organizations.
Slovakia passed a constitutional amendment in recent months limiting same-sex couples' rights and asserting national law over EU law, reflecting broader political polarization.
The case has shaken Slovakia, a small NATO member, and intensified political divisions, with Fico accusing opposition and media of fueling the attack without evidence.
Cintula’s lawyer stated he would likely appeal the verdict, indicating ongoing legal and political controversy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Slovak court has sentenced 72-year-old poet Juraj Cintula to 21 years in prison for shooting Prime Minister Robert Fico on May 15, 2024, during a government meeting. The act was reclassified as a 'terror attack' due to Cintula’s political motivation, with claims of 'moral despair' and protest against government policies, including halting military aid to Ukraine. Cintula described Fico as embodying arrogance and corruption, while the prime minister has accused the opposition and media of inciting the attack. The case has intensified political polarization in Slovakia, with Fico’s government increasingly aligning with Russia, criticising EU policies, and implementing authoritarian measures. A constitutional amendment limiting rights of same-sex couples was passed recently, reflecting broader societal shifts. Cintula’s lawyer has indicated a likely appeal of the verdict, underscoring the case’s ongoing legal and political significance.
title: Slovak court sentences poet that shot PM to 21 years for ‘terror attack’
